segments.text: I notice that you say in your autobiography, Professor Revell, that you grew up close to the sea and always were attached to and had the mystery of the sea about you.
Is that your explanation for how you ended up in oceanography?
Not exactly.
I was a graduate student.
I majored in geology at Pomona College.
Afterwards, I spent a year as a teaching assistant in the geology department at Pomona.
And then I went to Berkeley as a graduate student in geology and a teaching assistant there.
And the then director of the Scripps Institution

a man named Thomas Whalen Vaughan, came up to Berkeley looking for a geologist, a graduate student in geology, to spend a year at La Jolla looking at some mud, mud that had been collected from the deep sea floor by the non-magnetic yacht Carnegie.
Carnegie had a tragic end.
It blew up in the harbor of Apia in Samoa.
And the captain and the cabin boy were killed.
the ship was destroyed.
But they had the good sense to send all their samples off at every port they stopped at.
And they sent all their bottom samples, as we used to call them, samples of the bottom sediments.
They sent them back to Washington.
A man named John A. Fleming was then director of the Department of Terrestrial Magnetism

Carnegie Institution, which was the operator of this non-magnetic yacht, asked Braun if he or Pete, if the Scripps Institution could examine these, if somebody at Scripps could examine these sediments and write a report on them.
And Braun came to Berkeley looking for somebody to do this.
And there were two of us who tried for the job, a man named Bill Rand and I.
Interestingly enough, both of us ended up involved with the ocean.
Bill Rand was the operator of various kinds of equipment for the oil companies, for underwater oil exports.
I got the job.

And the reason I applied for the job was basically because I was about to get married to a woman named Ellen Clark, who was a Scripps College student and niece of Ellen Browning Scripps, more or less the patron saint of La Jolla.
And she had this house right here that her mother had.
It didn't look much like this then, but it was in this location, and the central part was there.
We'd come down here in the summertime, if you feel.
during our courting period, starting in 1927.
And she was just graduating from Scripps, and we were just about to get married.
And we thought it would be a good way to spend the first year of our married life here in La Jolla, where she was born, and where she'd spend her summer.
So I applied for the job and got it.
At that time, the Scripps Institution was a very small place.
There were only five graduate students.
And I believe there were only five faculty members.
And the total staff, counting the students in the faculty, was about 30 people.
And I started looking at these muds and learning about how you look at muds.
Two of the other graduate students were a man named Richard Fleming, Richard Howell Fleming.
who spent the last 25 years, I guess, thereabouts at the Oceanographic Laboratories of the University of Washington.
There was a man named Maynard Harding.
I don't really know what became of him.
They were both chemists.
And one afternoon, Dick Fleming came into my lab, the lab I was sitting in, and said,
Well, you're the new boy here, and we're supposed to go to sea tomorrow and take an oceanographic station.
And I said, OK. We got up about 2 o'clock in the morning.
We were all living out there at the Scripps Institution.
We had this group of little cottages around the
laboratory building, which had been built in 1960.
Dick Fleming lived in one of these, and Ellen and I lived in another.
He wasn't married then.
They came and picked me up about 2, 2.30 in the morning.
We drove down to San Diego to Point Loma, where the Scripps Institution ship was tied up.
The ship was an ex-purse singer called the Scripps, about 65 feet long.
It had one professional crew member, a guy named Murdoch Ross, a Scottish railroad engineer.
And he'd come down to San Diego from British Columbia.
I always used to say his idea of keeping a ship in good shape is to keep it covered with grease like a locomotive.
That wasn't quite true.
But he was primarily a railroad engineer, not in any way
But he ran the engine.
And then we three were the crew, Harding and Fleming and I.
We started out about 3.30 in the morning and went off Point Loma about 15 miles to a deep area which is known as the San Diego Craw.
And we started to take a station.
Scripps had a program.

started by one of the faculty members named Eric Moberg, the chemist, to make weekly observations of the nutrients in the water, the phosphate and the silica and the nitrate, and the oxygen content of the water, and the temperature and salinity of the water, and to collect plankton samples.
And we did this by stopping in one place and taking a series of vertical samples at different depths.
This one sample of each of about 15 depths.
This used to be called, probably still is called, an oceanographic station.
Along about 11 o'clock in the morning, the other guy said, well, you're the new boy, so it's your job to cook dinner.
So I went down to the galley, and I
Scripps has always had a policy of feeding very well.
We had steak and boiled potatoes and lettuce and tomato salad.
It was a very good, simple lunch.
And the other guys came down and ate this dinner in absolute silence, not saying a word.
Neither good nor bad, they just ate it.
That's the way sailors are.
They hardly ever say much when they're eating.
And after about 10 minutes, after they'd finished wolfing it down, they got up and said, well, it makes us seasick down here.
We better go up topside again.
You better do the dishes.
I didn't get seasick.
Well, I stayed and did the dishes and cleaned up.
Went back up and we finished the station.
And we came in back to San Diego.
And I remember we got back just about dusk.
Must have been about 7, 38 o'clock in the evening.
And this was an absolutely marvelous experience.
I'd never really been on a ship before in my life.
I'd gone down to the beach in the summertime.
We lived in Pasadena, and I was a little boy.
We lived in Redondo Beach.
And we'd go down to Balboa in the summertime.
I'd really never been on a ship before, except the old Congress that was there.
pastor's team had sailed up and down the West Coast.

This was such a wonderful experience that I decided right then and there I wanted to be an oceanographer, because you have this marvelous business of doing science and being a sailor at the same time.
So after that, we went out quite regularly on the Scripps.
was an old purse sinker.
That's an old fishing boat.
A fishing boat was used off this coast, a special kind of a net called a purse sinker.
And we never went very far.
But we used to organize cruises to sail in the Southern California waters about 100 miles offshore and about 150 miles north of here and a little ways to the south.
of studying the ocean, essentially the water, the water conditions off the California coast.
After a couple of years, this is 1931, about 1933 or 1934, I didn't see so much that I actually became the skipper of this little vessel.
a small boat operator's license up at San Pedro.
So I was in charge.
By that time, we had a cook as well as an engineer.
And I was the assistant engineer at first.
I used to, when we were on these cruises that lasted a week or more, I would spell the engineer, where he brought, in the engine room.
And later, we had this cook.
Frank, I've forgotten his last name.
And I used to insist that we keep the ship clean.
And I bossed the other graduate students around.
And there's research assistants around.
Some were not actually graduate students.
But they didn't like it very well.
I was fairly naughty.
very much like a skipper should be, I guess.
But anyhow, we all got along.
And we went on several of these small cruises lasting a week to two weeks, coming into port in San Clemente Island and Santa Monica, Santa Cruz Island, San Nicolas, and Santa Rosa.
Santa Barbara Island.
This is really in Catalina, too.
We used to anchor at the Iskansaw Catalina.
These were marvelous things to do.
And finally, 1936, after five years of this, I finally got through looking at this goddamn mud and got my doctor's degree at Berkeley.
The Scripps Institution was then part of the Graduate School at Berkeley, the outlying field station.
In the meantime, I've done quite a bit of work with Moberg and Fleming on the chemistry of seawater, particularly.
Fleming and I did some work on the solubility of calcium carbonate in seawater, one of the earliest papers published on that.
And Moberg and Greenberg, Revell and Allen published a paper on the buffer mechanism of seawater.
I was, I was, my contribution to this was to show that boric acid is part of the buffer system of sea water.
It's not only calcium, carbonate, the carbonates and bicarbonates and the cations like calcium and sodium, but also there's some effect of boric acid and that changes the
the relationship between pH and the amount of carbonate in the water.
And about 1933, Dr. Vaughan went on a year's sabbatical.
He was chairman of a committee of the National Academy of Sciences to look at oceanographic institutions all over the world.
And I was really lagging way behind looking at this mud.
I was doing all these other things on ocean chemistry.
And he wrote a letter back to Dr. Moberg, who was acting director of Scritch, saying, we've just got to get this fellow Revell back on the job of looking at this mud.
Otherwise, maybe we'll have to fire him.
And this was right in the middle of the Depression, 31 to 36.
And then Moberg was very much against that, because he thought I was doing OK, even though I was looking at the mud.
I was doing OK. And at one time during this period, the University of California was very short of money.
And they were thinking that they would have to fire all the research assistants down here.
Because I remember the faculty actually took a cut in their own salaries.
So they could keep on.
In order to keep the research assistants on, I believe the faculty actually took a voluntary reduction salary.
Another couple, and Ellen and I, were trying to prepare ourselves in case we did get laid off.
Her mother had a lemon grove up near Riverside, and we went up to look at that and see if we could live there and farm that, or grow lemons in that lemon grove.
It was not a very promising prospect.
Anyhow, they didn't lay us off, so we stayed on.
I finally got my thesis written on the marine bottom samples collected by the yacht Carnegie.
I got my PhD in the spring of 1936 at Berkeley.
That was when the Scripps Institution was part of the graduate division of the University of California at Berkeley.
UCLA didn't have a graduate division just when they graduated.
And it was clear that I was quite determined to stay on, so they promoted me to instructor.
My salary went from $1,200 a year to $1,800.
And I was an instructor.
I continued being an instructor until the war came along, and I went on active duty in the Navy.
That's in 1941, though.
Between 36 and 41, what sort of projects did you work on at Scripps?
Well, the first year, after from 36 to 37,
And our whole family went to Norway, where I had what would now be called a post-doctoral fellowship, although we paid for it, at the Geophysical Institute in Bergen.
And the man, Dr. Vaughan, retired in 1936, the summer that I
by my PhD.
His place was taken by Harold Sperger, who was a great Norwegian oceanographer, probably the best oceanographer of his time in physical oceanography.
The Norwegians were leaders in physical oceanography for about 50 years, about 40 years, I think, because of the influence of a man named Willem Bjerknes.
who was a theoretical physicist, who especially was hydrodynamics.
And he invented, well, he really applied hydrodynamics to planetary circulation, to both the ocean and the atmosphere.
And there was a whole group of Scandinavians at that time.
Alfred Ekman was the
better of the so-called Ekman spiral, which is the theoretical way that a wind-driven current turns to the right of the northern hemisphere as you go deeper in a spiral.
And Bjorn Helen Hansen, who was essentially a descriptive physical oceanographer, he was particularly concerned with the accuracy and variability of observations

He'd been a colleague of Fridtjof Nansen, the explorer and world citizen, who had invented something called the Nansen bottle, which is a bottle for sampling the water at different depths, an ingenious device for closing the bottle by the weight that you dropped on the cable when you wanted to close it.
Helen Hansen used these Nansen bottles and reversing thermometers to make very accurate measurements of temperature.
And the water samples that they collected, they could make very accurate measurements of salinity.
And from these, it was possible to compute the densities, the surfaces of equal density in the ocean and the surfaces of equal pressure or pressure differential.

And those people in Scandinavia, particularly Bjerkes and his followers, developed the theory of pressure-driven circulation in the ocean, in which the pressure gradient was balanced against Coriolis force, not really a force,
Because of the Earth's rotation, the currents turn it parallel to the pressure gradient instead of right angles to it, or nearly parallel.
The real balancing force, of course, is the force of friction.
But the only way you can get that to balance is to have the current running very close to parallel to the surface of equal pressure, running along the hill instead of down the hill.
And this theory of pressure-driven currents was an equilibrium theory.
It didn't allow for what we call convergence or divergence.
You had to have continuity at every plane, every horizontal plane.
Whereas what actually happens is that in some places the water
converges and sinks or rises.
In other places, they have divergence.
Actually, if you have convergence, the water sinks.
If you have divergence, the water rises and spreads out.
And that's this theory that didn't account for that.
Equine's theory, on the other hand, was based upon stress, but likewise based on the balance between Coriolis force and the stress of the wind.
friction, the friction of the wind on the sea surface.
And again, that's a second order.
Essentially, as a second order effect, the viscous friction in the water, so-called turbulent friction.
And there was a man named
Otto Pettersson in Sweden, who'd done a good deal of oceanographic observation.
Great Dane, who worked out, a man named Martin Knudsen, who worked out the methods of measuring salinity very accurately.
And the tables, the so-called Knudsen's tables, that enable you to translate temperature and salinity into density.
Eklund was involved with that, too.
And at the same time, there were a lot of great meteorologists there.
Bergen, Jock Bjerknes, Willem Bjerknes' son, and his name's Farah Pettersson.
Carl Gustav Rosby was a Swede who'd come to the United States, but he was really part of the Scandinavian school.
Although he spent quite a bit of time at MIT.

So during the early part of this century and up until after World War II, the principle, the leaders in this kind of physical oceanography, the study of the currents, or what used to call the motions of the oceans, were all
Scandinavians, mostly Norwegians, but some Swedes, some Danes, and some Germans.
And there was also a great Austrian named Albert Defant, D-F-A-N-T. A German named Meritz, and another one named Buist.
Buist was primarily a descriptive oceanographer.
All these people attended a meeting of the International Union of Geodesy and Geophysics in Edinburgh.
And I met them for the first time there.
Except for Sferter.
Sferter would come out here with his wife and child and daughter.
And I met him out here just briefly before we left.
And it turned out, actually, that I would have done better just to stay here and work with him.
But we had, in terms of research and learning,
We had a wonderful time in Norway, and the first time either of us had ever been outside the United States.
We had our two small daughters with us.
One of them was about four years old, and one was about three and a half, and one was about six months.
Then we went there, and of course, a year later when we came back, our oldest daughter got so she talked English with a strong Norwegian accent
Our youngest daughter was quite ill, had diarrhea.
And she just got thinner and thinner and punier and punier.
And I remember one night, we were very worried about her.
And I got on the streetcar.
We lived in a place called Hope, just outside of Bergen, next to another little suburb called Paradise.
I got in the street car and went into town, and I see a woman doctor named Johanna Scram Anderson.
I was scared to death that Mary was really sick.
And she gave me some fruit juice called Saft, and she said, give the child some of this several times a day.
We did, and she got well before the days of antibiotics.
or even sulfur drugs, I guess.
I'm not quite sure about that.
One of the people that we became very good friends with was one of the couples we became very good friends with were Jaak and Hedvig Bjerknes.
Jaak Bjerknes was the inventor of the theory of air mass analysis.
During World War I, he had the job of running what they called the Baerbarsling and Baubest line of weather forecasting for Western Norway.
Of course, there weren't any ship, very few ship reports, because the radios were all silent.
And he had somehow to make forecasts for the fishing vessels.
And he developed this theory of the polar, of the air mass front, fronts between air masses.
Air mass is a different physical characteristic.
One air mass is a slightly cold front in which the

cold air slid under the warm air in the warm front which the warm air slid up over the cold air and i learned something quite fundamental from him that was that you must leave a good scientist really lets nature take the lead that is that he would he would never try to force the weapon never try to have a
to have a theory about it or have a predilection about it.
He'd just lie back and let nature tell him what was going to happen.
And this was remarkable.
It said to rain 32 days out of every month in Bergen.
It does rain.
It does rain every day.
